title: Understanding Japan
requirements: Not for students who have taken JASP1020.
description: The course introduces students to major social and cultural issues in present-day Japan. It explores the important debates, problems, and challenges that have shaped Japanese society and culture in recent decades. The course encourages students to think critically about issues in Japanese society from a variety of disciplinary perspectives.
outcome: -state, recognize, recall and tell the main features of postwar Japan. Participants are expected to analyze the challenges faced by postwar and contemporary Japan and how they were surmounted successfully. -recognize, describe and clarify the strengths and weaknesses, the advantages and disadvantages of the features and characteristics of contemporary Japan. -compare and contrast Japanese developmental phases in the postwar years.  -apply, relate and deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics and interaction of selected Japanese political, social, environmental, demographic developments. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of major developments within Japan. Deepen their appreciation of the significance of the dynamics of Japan’s domestic society, economy and politics; its interaction with its neighboring region and the rest of the world; examine Japan’s coping mechanisms in interacting with globalization and major recent world trends.  -analyze Japan's structure, policies, economy, society and current trends. Analyze the causes and effects of internal and external influences on Japan's development. Analyze the challenges that Japan faces, its ways of managing them and the resulting innovative features. Develop analytical frameworks for these analyses. -generalize, reflect and hypothesize their own conclusions with regards to the course materials and contemporary issues  [Writing skills] Through the graded short essay exercise required in the course, class participants develop skills in essay-writing and library research such as literature review and analytical skills. It is also an opportunity for participants to put their creative ideas in writing.   [Interactive skills] Class participation and attendance facilitates interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints. The graded tutorials enhances interactions with other class participants, learning from each other and exploring alternative viewpoints through oral presentations that include class discussions and debates. Subject to availability, guest lectures may also be possible as opportunities for class participants to interact with individuals with specific relevant expertise.   [Reading skills] While lectures and tutorials are the main modes of knowledge exchange and learning activity, students are encouraged to critically examine the required readings and present their alternative viewpoints and comments in the tutorials.

title: Japanese Culture and Society
requirements: Not for Japanese Studies Majors or students who have taken UGEC1232
description: (UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100.) The main objective of this course is to give students a general idea of Japanese cultural history and social background of modern Japan. Guidance leading to a better understanding of Japan will be provided.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the main areas of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, and religion. They are expected to understand the ways in which Japanese see their own society in terms of economic growth, Japan's place in the world, social order, and political structure.   2) Students are expected to understand and be able to use a variety of social theories and perspectives in understanding Japan. They are also expected to have gained an understanding of how these same perspectives might be used to analyze their own society, or other societies which they may wish to study in the future.   3) Students are expected to develop a clearer understanding of their own values regarding work, leisure, marriage, family, love, and religion through a comparison with the debates and competing interpretations of these values in Japan.     Remarks: Department Board members disagreed with the suggestion that they replace the word 'understanding' with another word such as 'identity, explain, analyze or synthesize' as suggested by UGE.
syllabus: Week 1: Images of Japan This lesson introduces students to widespread popular images of Japan in Asian and Western media and academia. It considers how and why these images have changed over time and asks students to consider the usefulness and limits of generalizations about other people and societies.   Week 2: Nation, Nationalism and the Imperial System This lesson introduces students to theories explaining nationalism. It then uses these theories to consider nationalism in Japan. It explores the Japanese Imperial system in the context of historical developments in Japanese nationalism. Read:   1)   Akemi Nakamura. "Textbook Fight Not as Simple as it Seems" The Japan Times. 7 August 2005.                2)      Reiji Yoshida. "Panel Set to Ponder Female on the Throne." The Japan Times. 25 January 2005.   Week 3: The "Economic Miracle" This lesson explores two main theories behind Japan's economic development and subsequent recession of the 1990s. It considers the reasons for Japan's economic success, the experience of this success for Japanese people, and asks students to consider competing interpretations of Japan's economic development. Read: Kenneth B. Pyle, "Japan's Postwar National Purpose," chapter 3 in his The-Japanese Question: Power and Purpose in a New Era pp.20-41   Week 4: Law and Order This lesson examines changing perceptions of social order in Japan. It explores the catalysts behind these changing perceptions and considers the relationship between perceptions and reality. Students are asked to consider how Japan and their own societies maintain trust in the government, faith in social justice, and belief in the reliability of public order. Read:   1 )  Wolfgang Herbert. "Yakuza and the Law" In Harumi Befu, Tom Gill, Jeffery Eades (eds.). Globalization and Social Change in Contemporary Japan. Pp. 143-158.               2)   Michael Williams. "Revolving Door: Many Japanese Banks Ran Amok While Led by Former Regulars. Wall Street Journal (Eastern edition). Jan 19, 1996.   Week 5: Work and Workplaces This lesson introduces competing interpretations of Japan's employment strategies. It urges students to consider the reasons behind these competing interpretations. It also helps students to consider the system from the perspective of Japanese workers according to gender, age, and educational level, and encourages them to consider their own strategies and values as future members of their society's workforce. Read:   1)  Joy Hendry. "Careers and Continuity" in Understanding Japanese Society pp. 149-167               2)   Yamada, A. "Death of a Salaryman" Japan Quarterly. Jul-Sep 1999 vol. 46 (3): 40-47               3)   Mathews, Gordon. "Seeking a Career, Finding a Job: How Young People Enter and Resist the Japanese World of Work" In Gordon Mathews and Bruce White (eds.) Japan k Changing Generations: Are Young People Creating A New Society?               4)   Yuko Ogasawara. "Gossip" in Office Ladies and Salaried Men. pp. 70 - 97.   Week 6: Education This lesson introduces five theories that explain the role of education in society. Students are asked to consider how these theories may be useful in understanding Japan's educational system and philosophies. Students are encouraged to consider their own beliefs and principles regarding the purpose of education and their strategies as students-within theu educational system. Read:   1)   Joy Hendry. "The Education System" in Understanding Japanese Socieiy pp. 96-114              2)   Lee Cunin, Maria. 2004. "The Students Academic Experience: Students' Thoughts on Reform and the Future." In her Student Views in Japan: A Study of Japanese Students ' Perceptions of their First Years at University. Pp. 119-138   Week 7: Home and Family This lesson introduces several theories regarding the family in modem society. It then explores changes in Japanese family forms over time. Students are asked to articulate their own values toward love, marriage, and family in contrast to what they are learning about Japan. Read: 1) Joy Hendry. "The House and Family System" in Understanding Japanese Society pp.22-41            2) Anne Allison. "Family and Home" chapter 6 in Nightwork: Sexualify, Pleasure and Corporate Masculinity in a Tokyo Hostess Club pp. 102-113   Week 8: Women and Gender This lesson examines changes in women's and men's roles and ideals in Japanese society over time. Students are urged to reflect upon their own understandings of gender in comparison to perceptions and practices of gender common in Japan. Read:  1)  Surniko Iwao. "Myths and Realities " in The Japanese Woman: Traditional Image and Changing Reality. pp. 1-30             2)   Wiseman, Paul. USA Today. 'Wo Sex Please, We're Japanese." 2 June 2004.   Week 9: Leisure and Play This lesson explores the role of leisure in modem societies and the development of the concept and practices of leisure in modem Japan. Leisure in Japan is explored in terms of gender, age, class, and generational differences. Students are encouraged to articulate their own attitudes toward leisure in relation to work, to consider how perceptions of how leisure have changed over time in their society, and to discuss how they expect their own leisure practices will change as they age. Read: Anne Allison. "A Type of Routine." In Nightwork. P. 42-56.   Week 10: Mass Culture and Popular Culture This lesson explores the development of mass culture in Japan and explains the ways in which popular culture may serve as the basis for both social change and the reproduction of the status quo. Students are asked to consider how their own participation in popular culture and mass culture both generates changes in their societies and reproduces global capitalist structures. Read: Merry White. "The Marketing of Adolescence in Japan: Buying and Dreaming." In Lise Skov and Brian Moeran (eds.) Women, Media and Consumption in Japan. P. 255-273   Week 11: Religion This lesson explores basic religious traditions and philosophies in Japan and how the role of religion in Japan has changed over time. It considers the role of religion at the level of state politics as well as in everyday life. Theories regarding religion in modern society are introduced. Students are urged to develop their own interpretations of the role of religion in modern societies and in their own lives.  Read:   1)   Joy Hendry. "Religious Influences," Understanding Japanese Society. pp. 115-132               2)  Pfeiffer, William Sanborn. "Makihari: New Religion and Japanese Popular Culture" Journal of Popular Culture. Fall 2000 vol. 34. Iss. 2, pp. 155 – 174   Week 12: Student Presentations   Week 13: Conclusion This lesson reviews the social issues which Japanese consider to be most serious such as the emergence of diversity, subcultures, and changing youth expectations and desires regarding adulthood. It discusses, through surveys, how Japanese people view their society and how they view their future. It asks students to consider which problems are seen as the most critical in their societies, how their own societies view their future, and how popular views about their societies and about their societies' future are related to the beliefs held by individuals. Read: (Read one-quarter of letters) "Rethinking the War Experience." In Frank Gibney. (ed.) In SensG: The Japanese Remember the Pacific War Letters to the Editor of the Asahi Shimbun. pp. 283-318.

title: Understanding Japanese Languages and Culture
description: (UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120.) This course explores the relationship between Japanese language and culture. Everyday communication strategies adopted by people in Japanese society will be examined in terms of Japanese language expressions, styles and structures. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course but interdisciplinary approaches will also be adopted. This course is designed for students who are interested in knowing more about Japan but who have very limited or no knowledge of the Japanese language. Student will gain an understanding of the basic structure of the Japanese language, learn how usage of the language reflects Japanese culture and behavior, and explore how communication patterns of Japanese speakers differ from speakers of other languages.
outcome: 1. Students are expected to have gained a basic understanding of the structure of the Japanese language and historical changes of the writing system. Moreover, students will be able to understand the usage of the language, different styles and when each should be used, and different strategies used in expressing politeness. 2. Students are expected to understand the relationship between the language expressions and the behaviors of Japanese people in various circumstances and the reasons behind such behaviors. 3. Through comparing the culture of Japan with that of Hong Kong, students will become able to make comments on the characteristics of each and distinguish between the two. 4. Students will be able to perform an elementary study regarding Japanese culture and this will help the students to develop his/her further study in Japanese Studies.
syllabus: Week 1 Lesson 1 Introduction to Japanese culture: This lesson explains how Japanese culture influences daily life in Hong Kong today. The usage and the characteristics of Japanese language will also be discussed.   Week 2 Lesson 2 Introduction to the historical changes of kanji and kana in the Japanese language: This lesson explains the historical changes of kanji and kana in Japanese language. Focus will be on why Japanese absorbed Chinese characters into their writing system and the process of how Chinese characters were converted to the modern kana (hiragana and katakana).   Week 3 – Week 4 Lesson 3 Introduction to the phrases expressing linguistic politeness: This lesson briefly explains the phrases expressing linguistic politeness. These include honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.   Week 4 - 5 Lesson 4 Strategies used in making requests and refusals in Japanese:  This lesson discusses how Japanese make requests and refuse the requests of others. Such expressions are often used in daily life by Japanese but are not easily understood by foreigners. Special attention will be given to:  a. the difference in behaviour between Japanese and non Japanese in making requests and refusals. b. how this behaviour reflects characteristics of Japanese culture.    Week 6 – Week 7 Lesson 5 Strategies used in making apologies and taking responsibility: This lesson discusses how Japanese apologize and take responsibility after misconduct such as scandals or accidents. For example, we often see the top management of Japanese companies bow to the public to apologize for their misconduct and they may even quit the company in order to take responsibility for problems. In Hong Kong, it is rare to see such a phenomenon. We will discuss the mechanism of how Japanese make an apology and the effect of the Japanese way of apologizing upon social situations. Special attention will be given to the comparison of the styles of apology in Japanese and Hong Kong societies. We will also discuss the relationship between the Japanese way of apologizing and issues related to the Sino-Japanese War.   Week 8 – Week 9 Lesson 6 Ambiguity in the Javanese language: Compared with other languages such as Chinese, there are many ambiguous linguistic practices in Japanese. These include, for example, the deletion of the subject "watashi" (I), the use of "koto ni narimashita" (become something) rather than "koto ni shimashita" (I decided to do something) when talking about personal matters such as getting married, and the frequent use of intransitive verbs rather than transitive verbs. Most Japanese language learners including Hong Kong learners have experienced difficulties with these expressions and practices in their learning process. We will analyze and comment on this phenomenon.   Week 9 – Week 10 Lesson 7 The Business Manner of Japanese: This lesson discusses how Japanese behave in business negotiations. Japanese are often criticized for not stating their true feelings and opinions. They often use expressions such as "kangaesasetekudasai" (Please let me think about it), "kekkoo desu" (It's O.K. /No, thank you) to indirectly express their opinions. We will discuss why Japanese behave in such a way and the correct way to deal with a Japanese business partner.   Week 10 - Week 11  Lesson 8 Japanese language in a sociolinguistic perspective: In this lesson we discuss the following items of importance in sociolinguistics as they appear in the Japanese language. a. the comparison between written and colloquial styles b. the comparison of language usage for men and women c. the comparison between the standard language and dialect d. the comparison of language usage between the young and the elderly e. the comparison between formal styles and informal styles f. the comparison between jargon and standard expressions   Week 12 Lesson 9 The success and failure in learning Javanese language (with a focus on Hong Kong Cantonese speaking learners): First, we will give a brief introduction to the theories of second language acquisition. Next, the factors affecting the results of the process of second language learning will be discussed. To ensure a better understanding, case studies comparing English language acquisition among Japanese and Hong Kong people will be introduced. Finally, by summarizing the above observations and the characteristics of both Japanese and Cantonese, we will comment on the difficulties experienced by Hong Kong Cantonese speaking Japanese learners.   Week 13 Lesson 10 Special topics on Japanese 1anguage and Japanese culture:  Special topics will be selected to help students understand the relationship between Japanese language and culture. a. "shin go ryuukoogo taishoo" (New words and buzz terms Grand Prix) b. "kotoshi no kanji" (The Chinese character of this year)

title: Understanding Japanese Culture and Society Through Movies
requirements: Not for students who have taken GESC2080 or UGEC1302
description: (UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140.) Film is always regarded as an important medium for understanding society and culture. This course looks into the formation and characteristics of Japanese mentality and behaviour, through Japanese movies and academic readings of Japanese studies. This course consists of two major parts: 1) Lesson 2 to Lesson 7: Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies; 2) Lesson 8 to Lesson 12: Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to various academic readings, and will show movie clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.
outcome: Ø     Be able to understand the Japanese mentality and behaviour.    Ø     Acquire the ability to examine and investigate the academic and cultural meanings of movies from a macroscopic – cross-border, cross-era, interdisciplinary – perspective.    Ø     Be able to extract and digest messages carried in movies, in order to obtain a more thorough understanding of the relationships between Japan and other countries, including China, Korea and America.    Ø     Acquire a more thorough understanding of the influence of Japanese culture.    Ø     Further develop their critical thinking, presentation and writing skills through interactive teaching methods such as discussions, classwork and essay writing.
syllabus: Lesson 1 Introduction (課程介紹) This lesson introduces the objectives and learning approach of this course.   Part 1 (Lesson 2 to Lesson 7) Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies (從電影看日本人的自我觀) This part brings out different predominant theories on Japanese mental structure, and discusses whether they can be applied to the Japanese mentality revealed in Japanese movies produced from the post-war period to present, so as to investigate the degree of their validity.   Lesson 2 Japanese Hierarchy and Bushido (日本的階級觀念與武士道) This lesson discusses the function of hierarchy in Japanese society, and the important role of bushido in establishing the traditional Japanese ideals of conduct. Readings: Kurosawa-Film Studies and Japanese Cinema, and《武士道》   Lesson 3 Japanese Moral Standards and the Shame Culture (日本道德觀與恥的文化) This lesson compares the Japanese shame culture to the guilt culture by investigating the relationship between groupism and individualism in Japan, and sees how it shapes the Japanese moral standards. Readings: The Anatomy of Dependence, and《日本倫理思想與日本現代化》   Lesson 4 Passive Individualism Among the Youth (日本新一代的被動個人主義) This lesson examines the difference between individualism in Japanese new generation’s view of love and that of traditional thinking, and investigates the profound influences of Japanese movies and television culture on young people. Readings: The Creative Edge: Emerging Individualism in Japan“Transcending the Outsider’s Role: A Japanese Superstar in Japan and Hong Kong”, and   Lesson 5 Japan’s Return to Asia: Political Meaning Behind the Boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro (金城武熱潮的形成和意義) This lesson discusses the transformation of Japanese identification of being Asian from the Meiji Westernization to the age of globalization, by examining the political meaning behind the boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro in the 1990s. Reading: “Facing Challenges in a New Age: A Multicultural and New Generation Identity for Japan, through Kaneshiro Takeshi and Kubotsuka Yōsuke”   Lesson 6-7 A New Stage in Japan-China and Japan-Korea Relationships (對中和對韓的日本新觀) This lesson analyzes the new views on China and Korea revealed in Japanese movies produced from the 1990s to present.   Readings: Interpreting History in Sino-Japanese Relations, and 《東亞三國的近現代史》   Part 2 (Lesson 8 to Lesson 12) Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others (比較日本與其他民族集團的思維模式) Through the comparison between movies of Japan and other nations, this part focuses on the different thinking patterns of Japan and others.   Lesson 8 Japanese Self-Deprecation and Male Chauvinism (日本自嘲文化與男尊女卑) Through the comparison of comedies of Japan and America, this lesson investigates the unique culture of self-deprecation, and the different roles of men and women in Japan.   Readings:Beyond Common Sense: Sexuality and Gender in Contemporary Japan, and Different Games Different Rules - Why American and Japanese Misunderstand Each Other.   Lesson 9 The Logic and Influence of Amae (“依愛”的邏輯與影響) This lesson discusses how amae (dependence) affects the Japanese logical thinking and behaviour by comparing suspense movies of Japan, Hong Kong and Korea. Readings: “Higaisha-ishiki: The Psychology of Revolting Youth in Japan,”  《日本的自我：社會心理學家論  日本人》及〈《花樣奇緣》呈現的日本人精神面貌〉   Lesson 10 Imaged Masculinity and the Aesthetics of Violence (男性想像與暴力美學) This lesson investigates the meaning of ninjo (human feelings) and giri (obligation), and the relationship between Japanese yakuza culture and gangster films. It also compares the different points of view of Takeshi Kitano and Quentin Tarantino in presenting the “aesthetics of violence” and “tragic hero”. Readings: The Chrysanthemum and the Sword: Patterns of Japanese Culture, and Myth and Masculinity in the Japanese Cinema: Towards a Political Reading of the “Tragic Hero”.   Lesson 11 Self and Others: A Comparison of Japanese and American Godzillas (日美哥斯拉呈現的 “我” 與“他”) This lesson investigates the socio-political meanings of Godzilla in Japan, and looks into the different viewpoints on the concepts of “others” between Japanese and American monster films.  Readings: Hibakusha Cinema: Hiroshima, Nagashima, Nagasaki, and the Nuclear Image in Japanese Film; and “From Godzilla to Train Man: A Study of the Japanese Self Image in the Context of the West”   Lesson 12 Cinderella & Women Warrior: A Comparison of Disney and Miyazaki’s Heroines (比較日美動畫中的女性形象) This lesson investigates the Japanese national spirit revealed in animations, compares the different images of female characters in Hayao Miyazaki’s and Disney’s animations, and examines their different cultural significance. Readings: Mouse Morality: The Rhetoric of Disney Animated Film, and Anime from Akira to Princess Mononoke: Experiencing Contemporary Japanese Animation   Lesson 13 Mid-Term Report Review and Conclusion (中期報告成績討論與課程總結)         A follow-up discussion of the mid-term reports submitted by students; and a general review     of the topics, discussions and materials covered in the course, and helps students to     prepare for the final examination.

title: Japanese Popular Culture in Cultural Globalization
requirements: Not for students who have taken JASP1110 or UGEC1271
description: (UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160.)  This course examines the development and academic significance of various forms of Japanese popular culture such as films, comics, music, TV dramas and culinary culture, from multidisciplinary perspectives, including history, cultural anthropology, cultural studies and media studies. It aims to deepen understanding the following three facets of Japanese popular culture:1) the applicaton of cultural globalization theory in Japan; 2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries; and 3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Using concrete examples and grounding on representative academic writings, this course discusses the globalization of Japanese popular culture and relevant issues in indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows and media-mix. Students are trained to understand the nature and cultural implications of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context. Besides lectures, discussions and readings, this course selectively utilizes topical essays (projects), e-learning, audio-visual materials and fieldwork-based assignments as supplementary teaching tools.
outcome: Through a historical and cultural analysis of different facets of Japanese popular culture, this course aims to achieve the following three academic goals:1)      It aims to use Japanese popular culture as a medium or stepping stone to enhance students’ interest in and understanding of Japanese history, society and culture.2)      It aims to deepen understanding of nature and impact of Japanese cultural industry and its cultural implications in an Asian context.3)      It aims to discuss Japanese popular culture within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. Having taken this course, students will be equipped with a basic ability to analyse cultural phenomenon in the lens of such cultural concepts as indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows, media mix, cultural colonialism and orientalism.
syllabus: Main Objective:This main purpose of course is to examine the global popularization and localization of Japanese popular culture from historical, cultural and comparative perspectives within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. It aims to indicate that the cultural flows between Japan and Asia are by no means one-way traffic and Asia has been interacting and collaborating with the Japanese in creating, manufacturing, marketing and distributing cultural products for decades. Lectures, discussions and readings highlight different facets of cultural acculturation and transnational interaction found in Japan-Asia cross-cultural flows, such as appropriation, hybridization, global localization business strategy, the making of localized editions, the local application of Japanese formula, joint production, and the participation of foreign artists and staff. Solidly grounding on empirical data as well as theories from cultural globalization and cross-cultural studies, this course will be a pioneering teaching and learning project to explore uncharted research territories in Japanese studies, Japan-Hong Kong relations, and cultural studies. Key Issues and Problems:The following key issues and problems regarding the globalization of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context will be addressed in this course within the theoretical fiarnework of cultural globalization: 1) The idea that the influx of Japanese cultural products is a form of cultural imperialism that aims to expand Japanese economic interest and to spread Japanese value and lifestyle in Asia will be empirically and theoretically reexamined and challenged. It shows that cultural imperialism is an outdated model in cross-cultural studies, because it fails to understand the dynamic mechanism in transnational cultural flows and cultural forces of localization and hybridization.2) While using "glocalization" (Roland Robertson uses it to refer to the localization strategy employed by multi-national companies to promote their products in different nations) to investigate the global business strategy of Japanese companies such as Sony, Nintendo, Capcom and Bandai in Asian and global markets, this course underscores the limitation of the glocalization theory in the East Asian context, as it fails to see the initiative taken by Asian artists and businessmen to creatively and selectively domesticate Japanese elements.3) This course uses Japanese popular culture as a mirror or text to decode social and cultural issues of contemporary Japan. For examples, themes about ethnicity, gender, social hierarchy, political ideology, and cultural identity will be examined in the lens of Japanese popular culture. Core Content, Structure and Selected Topics:The course content of this course investigates the three facets of Japanese popular culture: (1) the application of cultural globalization theory in Japan, (2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries, (3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Accordingly, its structure follows the design of core content and contains the following three parts: Part 1: Japanese Popular Culture and Cultural Globalization: Theories and PracticesSelected Topics:(a) Introduction to Basic Theories in Cultural Studies and Cultural Globalization(b) Globalization of Japanese Popular Culture in an Asian Context(c) Reexamining the Cultural Imperialism, Orientalism and Nihonjinron  Discourses(d) Indigenization and Hybridization of Japanese Popular Culture in Asia (1) Food and Fashion(e) Indigenization and Hybridization of Japanese Popular Culture in Asia (2) TV Programs Part 2: Interplay between Globalization and JapanesenessSelected Topics:(a) Nihonjinron in Japanese Movies and Alternative Mode of Globalization(b) The Formation of Japanese Manga and Anime and Their Hybridity(c) The Making of an Otaku Culture in Japan and Beyond(d) The Adaptation of Chinese Tradition in Japanese popular culture Part 3: The Global Strategy of Japanese Cultural IndustriesSelected Topics:(a) Glocalization of Japanese Video Games and Cyber Culture(b) Transnational Collaboration and Cross-cultural Themes in Japanese Movies(c) Japaneseness and Universality in Japanese Comics and Animated Series(d) Exporting and Domesticating Japanese Formula in Asian Drama and Music(e) Media-mix as a Business Strategy in Japanese Cultural Industries

title: Modern Sino-Japanese Relations
description: Sino-Japanese relations are an important dimension of the history of modern East Asia. This course analyzes this multifaceted relationship from the mid-19th century to the present day. It will pay special attention to such topics as mutual perception, territorial and historical disputes, immigration, boycotts and collaboration, cultural diplomacy, postwar rapprochement, and attempts to move into a new age of Sino-Japanese coexistence. A main theme of discussion will be the need for accommodation and cooperation despite continual tension between the two countries.
outcome: 學生完成本科目後，將能：  1. 從多角度理解19世紀中葉至今中、日兩國在政治、外交、經濟、軍事、民間社會、教育及文化等方面的關係的起伏發展，以及兩國關係對東亞地區發展的重要性；  2. 掌握有關現代中、日兩國關係的基本概念、知識及理論，如華僑和日僑的形成與發展、中國留日學生的活動、中國人的反日、附日活動、日本對華文化教育政策、兩國相互認識之變化、兩國間的多種糾紛，以及中國威脅論、中國機遇論等重要輿論的產生等；  3. 全面了解中、日兩國在各個方面的衝突和協作關係，尤其明白各領域的關係彼此影響互動的複雜性；  4. 透過參觀在香港日本國總領事館或在港日本文化宗教團體，認識日本官方對華的立場和政策，以及在華日本民間團體的多元化活動；  5. 透過講授課堂尤其導修課堂，養成研習中、日兩國關係的比較視野和批判分析思維，如評估中、日文獻中有關證據或事例在多少程度上說明兩國關係的某(些)方面，或檢查近人著作中的事例能否證明作者的論點；  6. 就現代中、日兩國關係的重要課題，參考各種文獻資料和近人著作，撰寫具邏輯性、連貫性及創意的評論短文；  7. 自行蒐集和分析有關中、日兩國關係的資訊，由此客觀地展望兩國關係的演進發展。  Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. comprehend the development of Sino-Japanese relations in the aspects of politics, diplomacy, economic and military affairs, society, education and culture since the mid19 century and the importance of the relations to East Asia in multiple perspectives   2. master the basic concepts, knowledge and theories of modern Sino-Japanese relations including the evolution of the Chinese society in Japan and the Japanese society in China, the Chinese students’ activities in Japan, the Chinese resistance and collaboration with the Japanese, the Japanese cultural and education policy towards China, the mutual perception and disputes between the Chinese and the Japanese, and the theories of ‘China Threat’ and ‘China Opportunity’, etc;   3. thoroughly understand the conflicts and collaborations between China and Japan in different aspects and especially their interwoven interaction;  4. comprehend the standpoint and policy of the Japanese government towards China and various activities of the Japanese private organizations in China particularly by visiting Consulate-General of Japan or other cultural and religious organizations in Hong Kong;   5. develop comparative perspective and critical and analytical thinking on various aspects of modern Sino-Japanese relations, such as evaluating how far the evidence or examples in the Chinese and Japanese sources illustrate particular aspect(s) of Sino-Japanese relations, and checking whether they substantiate the writer’s claims;  6. write logical, coherent and creative essay on important issue(s) of modern Sino-Japanese relations based on different sources and recent studies;  7. collect and analyze various data about Sino-Japanese relations to look into the future relations objectively.
syllabus: 1. 德川時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Tokugawa Japan)  本課探討德川時代日本華僑社會形成的背景、因素及過程，又考察長崎華僑融入日本社會，改變居住生活形態的發展，以及中國儒學對德川時期二元政治體制盛衰之影響。  2. 明治、大正時代在日之華人 (The Chinese in Meiji and Taisho Japan)  本課分析19世紀末即明治後期中國人留學日本潮流產生的背景、因素及具體情況，並探究大正時代留日潮流的反覆發展，以及留日學生的政治化趨勢。   3. 中日甲午戰爭 (1894-1895) (The First Sino-Japanese War 1894-1895)  本課分析甲午戰爭爆發的背景和始末、戰爭期間及以後清朝對日觀念的變化，以及戰後的中日關係 發展。   4. 在清朝民國之日本人 (The Japanese in Qing and Republican China)  本課探討甲午戰爭前日本人在華的情報活動和戰爭前後日本人在華經營的通信報刊活動。  5. 日本對華之文教政策 (The Japanese Cultural and Education Policy towards China)  本課考察近代日本在華文教活動的產生及發展、各種教育活動的內容，以及二次大戰期間日本在學校推行的同化教育。  6. 華人的反日與附日 (The Chinese Resistance and Collaboration with the Japanese)  本課一方面探討民初、五四運動時期中國教科書的反日思想、1928年五三慘案以後的反日運動，另一方面分析抗日戰爭期間附日勢力出現的原因，諸勢力的類型、活動以及日本招攬漢奸的政策。  7. 二戰後在日之華人I (The Chinese in Postwar Japan I)  本課探討二次大戰以後至今日本華僑的人數增長情況、中華街華僑的經濟事業發展，以及新一代華僑的經濟結構變化。  8. 二戰後在日之華人II (The Chinese in Postwar Japan II)  本課考察二次大戰以後至今日本新舊數代華僑的不同程度同化情況，又探討 戰後華僑學校的教育問題及華僑的婚姻觀念演變。  9. 駐華之日本外交官 (The Japanese Diplomat on China)  本課說明駐華日本國總領事館包括在香港日本國總領事館的主要角色，指出日本領事充當促進中、日溝通、深化兩國關係的橋樑，並以近來數任在香港日本國總領事的訪問和演講，揭示近來日本的對華政策。  10. 中日的相互理解 (Mutual Perception between the Chinese and the Japanese)  本課考察在近、現代各階段中、日兩國的相互認識和觀感的演變發展及其諸發展跟兩國政治、外交、經濟、軍事等方面變化的互動關係，並探討近年中日兩國致力構築相互認識的平台的趨勢。  11. 日本與中國威脅論 (Japan and the ‘China Threat’ Theory)  本課考察1980年代至今中國的急速經濟發展及經貿策略演變，並分析90年代以來東亞國家經貿分工結構的轉變、中國跟東亞諸國尤其日本的經貿關係發展，以及日本先後產生「中國威脅論」和「中國機會論」的輿論變化。  12. 中日糾紛 (Sino-Japanese Disputes)  本課分析1990年代以來影響中、日兩國關係的國際環境和日本國內環境的種種變化，以及損害兩國關係的若干因素，包括日本政治右傾化問題、兩國的歷史觀衝突、靖國神社參拜問題、新「日美防衛合作指針」及台灣問題等等。  13. 中日關係的前景 (The future of Sino-Japanese Relations)  本課探討中、日兩國在亞洲地區共同化解衝突，協作發展的前景，如共同維持東亞地區的和諧穩定，促進該區的經濟互惠合作、安全和平及災難處理等發展方向。

title: Tourism and Sustainable Development
description: (UGEC1372 is double-coded with JASP1190.) Since 2015, tourism has been listed by the United Nations as one of the means to achieve sustainable development goals. How does tourism contribute to the sustainable development of human society? What are the impacts of tourism upon the cities and communities? Using Japan as a principal example, this course aims at examining the possibilities and challenges of achieving sustainable development goals through tourism. The first part of this course introduces basic concepts of tourism and sustainable development goals, and discusses their relationship. The second part of the course compares Japan to China and other countries, and investigates the benefits and costs of tourism in relation to sustainable cities and communities, indigenous culture, and natural resources. Additional discussions further explore the potentials of sustainable tourism in Hong Kong. With assigned readings and coursework, students are expected to acquire knowledge on sustainable development goals, and critically evaluate tourism as a means to achieve these goals.
outcome: By the end of this course, students are expected: 1.)     to acquire knowledge on UN’s sustainable development goals, and to apply their knowledge to critically evaluate the current situations in Hong Kong, Asia and the world; 2.)     to be able to critically evaluate tourism as a means to achieve sustainable cities and communities; 3.)     to be able to scholarly compare Japan to other countries in relation to tourism; 4.)     to reflect on tourism development in Hong Kong.
syllabus: Part One – Overview Week 01: Overview: Why Do People Travel? How Does Traveling Relate to Sustainable Development Goals?  This lecture topic introduces basic theories in social studies of tourism, and the current discussions on tourism in relation to sustainable development goals. Week 02: Introduction to Sustainable Development Goals  This lecture topic further examines the UN Sustainable Development Goals, and requests students to discuss the possible challenges of achieving these goals through tourism. Week 03: The Sustainable Destination  There is no tourism without destinations. This lecture topic examines features that make a destination sustainable. Week 04: Overtourism? Cases of Kyoto, Macau and Venice  Overtourism is one of the keywords that address the problems incurred by tourism. Drawing cases from both Europe and Asia, this lecture topic examines these problems, and invites students to suggest solutions. Part Two – Sustainable Development and Tourism in Japan and Beyond Week 05: Overview of Tourism in Japan  This lecture topic introduces the socioeconomic background in the historical development of tourism in Japan. Drawing Japan as an example, students are encouraged to reflect on the social and political agenda of tourism. Week 06: Gentrification: The Impacts of Urban Tourism  This lecture topic examines the problem of urban gentrification and its relation to tourism in Japan, China and beyond. Week 07: Mega Events  Drawing on the Olympic Games as one of the examples, this lecture topic scrutinizes the effects and impacts of hosting mega events to attract tourists in Japan and beyond. Week 08: Cultural Heritage and Local Communities  This lecture topic scrutinizes the impacts of tourism on local communities at world cultural heritage sites. Week 09: Environment and Ecotourism  The lecture topic examines ecotourism and its impact on the local and global environment. Week 10: Tourism and Indigenous Culture  This lecture topic investigates the role and impact of tourism on the sustainability of indigenous culture. Week 11: Tourism and Rural Revitalization  This lecture topic focuses on the possibilities and challenges of introducing tourism for sustainable development in depopulating regions in Japan and beyond. Week 12: Tourism and Disasters  This lecture topic discusses the phenomenon of transforming places associated with tragedy into tourist attractions, its cultural meanings, and social impacts upon local communities in Japan and beyond. Week 13: Discussion: Sustainable Development and Tourism in Hong Kong and Japan  During the concluding lecture, students are invited to exchange their views on sustainable development in Hong Kong, in comparison to Japan and other localities discussed over the semester.

title: Japanese Language Tasting
requirements:
Not for students who have taken JASP1450-1490,2000,2450-2490,3180,3200,3310-3390,3600,4180,4310,4330,4350-4390,4440,4450,4510,4520
From 2023-24, students can only earn up to 2 units of these courses: CLCP/C1001,1101,JASP1350,HKSL/SPAN/GERM/KORE/FREN1001
description: [This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]This course aims to provide a ‘tasting’ opportunity for students who have no history of Japanese language learning before to start their first Japanese language learning. The topics in this course will cover pronunciation of ‘Kana’, simple daily life communication topics to express their favorite food, interest/hobby, shopping, places they want to go/things they want to do in Japan, etc. In order to have a better understanding of Japanese society, relevant Japanese cultural topics will also be included in this course. After completing this course, students will have basic knowledge of Japanese ‘Kana’ and be able to communicate in simple Japanese language with Japanese people on topics introduced in this course. For students who opt for further study in Japanese language, this course will provide a good foundation for them to have a smooth transition to the upcoming elementary course. On the other hand, for students who do not opt for further study, this course will also provide simple basic language knowledge for daily conversation with Japanese people while visiting Japan in the future.Students who have attended any one year exchange study programme in Japan and/or passed any level of Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) are NOT allowed to take this course.
outcome: 1. Students can recognize the pronunciation of Japanese ‘Kana’.  2. Students can understand some basic vocabularies and grammar patterns.  3. Students can communicate verbally in simple Japanese with basic vocabularies and grammar patterns in some common situations.
syllabus: There are 7 modules (M1-M7) in this course.      M1 Introduction of pronunciation of Japanese ‘Kana’ and greeting    M2 My self-introduction & Japanese culture topic 1    M3 My favorite food & Japanese culture topic 2    M4 My interest and hobby & Japanese culture topic 3    M5 Shopping & Japanese culture topic 4    M6 Tell someone what you want to do & Japanese culture topic 5    M7 Tell someone where you want to go & Japanese culture topic 6

title: New Practical Japanese I
description: This course provides basic training in the Japanese language. Emphasis is placed on sentence pattern practice and basic grammar. It also includes oral drills, simple compositions, dictation, translation and reading. This course starts from the writing system and basic pronunciation. Course textbooks, course exercise books, examination papers and other course materials are written in Chinese and Japanese. Students taking this course are expected to have prior knowledge in the Chinese language. Advisory: Not for Japanese Studies Majors.
outcome: 1. use verbs of state (iru, aru), directional verbs (kuru, iku, kaeru) , and activity verbs (taberu, nomu, and benkyoosuru).  2. count and use appropriate quantifiers.  3. use na-adjectives and i-adjectives, and be able to conjugate according to the given situation.  4. use past and present tense, and continuous and resultative aspect appropriately.  5. use purpose expressions, such as V+ni.  6. use direct and indirect speech  7. ask when one doesn’t know how to read and what to say (~nan to iimasuka ~doo omoimasuka)  8. use secondary aspect of ~te aru  9. use particles of wa, ga, ni, de, and o.  10. speak with correct pronunciation.
syllabus: JAS1450 and 1460 are consecutive one-semester courses designed to provide comprehensive training in reading, listening, speaking and writing in Japanese at the elementary level for elective students with an emphasis on elementary grammar.  Students are required to attend four hours of language lessons per week and are expected to spend two hours on homework each week. Language lessons are conducted in four languages: Japanese, English, Cantonese and Mandarin. Teachers use various kinds of conversational practices based on natural conversation emphasizing the use of the language in context.  The examination papers are written in Chinese and Japanese, and it contains task(s) of Chinese to Japanese translation. Depending on the situation, an English translation of the Chinese texts can be provided for reference. However, in case there is any inconsistency or conflict in the translation between the Chinese and English texts, the Chinese version shall prevail.   After completing the courses, students are expected to reach novice-middle level, and continue to enrol in the intermediate level language courses.
required_readings: JASP 1450 Text Books and Homework  『日本語1』and『日本語 1 Workbook』written and published by Department of Japanese Studies, CUHK.  The course textbooks (including grammar explanations and translation sections) are written in Chinese and Japanese, and there are Chinese to Japanese translation questions in the exercise books used. The language used for classroom teaching varies from teacher to teacher. Students should refer to “Class Details” for information about medium of instruction for individual classes.

title: Japanese Pronunciation I
description: This course is designed for students studying JASP1460/1480 who wish to understand and pronounce Japanese accurately. Students will practice the contents of the course book Nihongo 2 focusing on pronunciation and grasp the basic sound patterns of Japanese. The teacher will also introduce related cultural elements such as J-pop music if time allows.

title: Japanese Communication Skills for Beginners 1
description: This course aims to provide students with the opportunity to develop basic interactive skills in Japanese. Through interactive involvement in class activities, students will develop basic linguistic skills and socio-cultural competencies involved in interacting with Japanese speakers in everyday social situations in Japan and Japan-related contexts in Hong Kong. The course is designed for students with only very limited or no prior learning experience in Japanese. The medium of instruction is English and course materials are written in English and Japanese.

title: Japan: History, Culture and Modernity
description: This course interrogates the major institutions, ideas and historical forces that shape life in contemporary Japan, and pushes students to examine the similarities and differences in processes of modernization across societies. As students have covered the historical and sociopolitical groundings of modern and contemporary Japan, this course goes deeper into the social science of Japan by examining the major social institutions of home, school, and work to facilitate our understandings of the primary forces of socialization and organization and the dynamics of power in contemporary Japanese social life. Furthermore, it addresses the new challenges emerging within each of these spheres based on Japan’s changing socio-economic and demographic landscapes. The study of Japan challenges us to reevaluate the premises of Western social theory as well as HK-centric conceptualization, and it rewards us with fresh understandings of the transformations to modernity and the nature and direction of modern life. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
outcome: Students will be able to gain a broad grasp of how Japanese society as well as its broader issues are approached and analyzed.  Students will also be able to articulate thoughtful and well-founded opinions based on their understanding of course materials.  In addition, students will develop critical thinking skills, construct analytical essays, give PowerPoint presentations, and lead academic discussions.

title: Critical Analysis in Japanese Studies
description: The course provides students with the opportunity to analyze primary and secondary sources on Japanese history, society, and culture. Students will be introduced to methods of analysis and exposed to various types of primary sources. Students will write a research paper and present findings on a specialized topic using primary data and will learn to identify, use, and analyze appropriate academic sources in relation to the chosen topic. Teamwork and individual work will be required.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to: analyze different kinds of primary sources assess and articulate the significance of primary sources in social and historical contexts and at national, regional, or global levels as appropriate identify and analyze academic sources written in relation to particular social issues use effective oral, written, and visual communication skills to make a sustained argument about a topic of interest about Japan. collaborate effectively as part of a team in professional and inter-disciplinary contexts

title: Field Research Methods
description: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of basic research methods for independent field research. Research methods such as interviewing, questionnaires, participant observation, and media surveys will be introduced and the merits of each will be discussed. The course will teach students how to design a research project and write a research proposal. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
outcome: Students will gain an understanding of the merits and limitations of a variety of qualitative research methods. Students will be able apply selected social science methodology to design their own research project in Japan.

title: Japan and Asian Creative Industries
description: This course examines the rise of Japan and Korea as leaders in global and regional creative and cultural industries from historical, sociological, ethnological and cultural perspectives. Lectures and tutorials cover areas in on-line games, idol-making, creative design, mobile phone culture, toys, film collaborations, etc. Lectures are theme-oriented with an aim to explore the role of the government and the private sectors in developing creative industries and the lesson for Hong Kong to learn from Japanese and Korean experiences.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to: Enhance the understanding of Japan and Asia’s cultural industries;  Gain updated information from experts in the industry. Analysis cultural phenomenon in Asia’s Cultural and Creational Industries systematically with independent thoughts. Discover concrete directions of development of HK’s Cultural and Creational Industries.

title: Introduction to Japanese Animation, Comic and Game
description: Animation, comic and game (ACG) are perhaps the most globalized parts of Japanese popular culture. They have a very strong impact on global cultural industry and consumer culture, used by the Japanese companies to expand their economic activities overseas and by the Japanese government for cultural politics. This course examines issues relating to Japanese animation, comic and game from historical, sociological and comparative perspectives. In addition to lectures, this course promotes interactive teaching and learning by organizing group discussion, video session and panel discussion.
outcome: Students are expected to achieve the following three learning outcomes after studying this course:(1) Have a deeper understanding of Japan's ACG industry and hence inspire a shared vision for local cultural industries;(2) Analyze the interactive relationship between ACG culture and society;(3) Apply academic theories to research and acquire the ability to analyze ACG works independently.

title: Culture of Japanese Mass Media
description: This course discusses the cultural and social implications of mass media in contemporary Japan. Media contexts in Japan are not only regarded as a business or an entertainment but also an ideology, or a remarkable source of soft power in the world's different media capitals. This course focuses on the construction of the Japanese mass media context in the age of internet and globalization, investigating how the media contexts are being produced and manipulated and how the influence is being demonstrated.

title: New Practical Japanese III
description: This course is the continuation of JASP1460. Course textbooks, course exercise books, examination papers and other course materials are written in Chinese and Japanese. Students taking this course are expected to have prior knowledge in the Chinese language. Students are required to pass a placement test or obtain equivalent competence in Japanese before course registration.Advisory: Not for Japanese Studies Majors.
outcome: 1) make complex sentences including time, quotations, conditionals, noun modifier, etc.  2) use basic functional phrases including purpose, cause, comparison, inference, etc.  3) use a variety of functional phrases including viewpoint, evaluation, hypothetical conditions, correspondence, tendency,   assertion, etc.  4) write simple texts following given structures and contents.  5) scan key words and skim over simple reading materials.  6) speak with correct pronunciation
syllabus: JAS2450 and 2460 are consecutive one-semester courses designed to provide comprehensive training in reading, listening, speaking and writing in Japanese at the intermediate level for elective students with an emphasis on both comprehension and expression.   Students are required to attend four hours of language lessons per week and are expected to spend two hours on homework each week. Language lessons are conducted in four languages: Japanese, English, Cantonese and Mandarin. Teachers use various kinds of conversational practices based on natural conversation emphasizing the use of the language in context.   The examination papers are written in Chinese and Japanese, and it contains task(s) of Chinese to Japanese translation. Depending on the situation, an English translation of the Chinese texts can be provided for reference. However, in case there is any inconsistency or conflict in the translation between the Chinese and English texts, the Chinese version shall prevail.  After completing the courses, students are expected to reach the intermediate-low level of Japanese language ability.
required_readings: JASP 2450 Text Books and Homework  『日本語3』and『日本語 3 Workbook』written and published by Department of Japanese Studies, CUHK.  The course textbooks (including grammar explanations and translation sections) are written in Chinese and Japanese, and there are Chinese to Japanese translation questions in the exercise books used. The language used for classroom teaching varies from teacher to teacher. Students should refer to “Class Details” for information about medium of instruction for individual classes.

title: New Comprehensive Japanese IV
description: The first part of this course covers grammar points in the second half of syllabus in elementary Japanese language (e.g. Causative form of verbs, Causative Passive form of verbs, Conditional clauses (‘ba’, ‘tara’, ‘nara’), Honorific expressions, etc.). This course aims to strengthen the comprehensive language skills in ‘Listening’, ‘Speaking’, ‘Reading’ and ‘Writing’. The second part of this course covers the grammar patterns and vocabularies in Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) level N2. The content of listening and reading comprehension of JLPT level N2 will be covered by applying exercises and drills. Advisory: For Japanese Studies Majors only.
outcome: After the completion of this course, students are able to perform the following issues.  1. Describe presumptive topics by using conditional clause.  2. Use causative form to describe actions which compelling someone to do something or giving permission to someone to do something.  3. Communicate by using honorific expressions in formal occasions.  4. Acquire knowledge necessary to pass Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) level N2.  .

title: Japanese Pronunciation II
description: This is an interactive Japanese pronunciation course for students who are taking JASP2460/JASP2480. Classes will focus on oral practices, using contents from the course books Nihongo 3 and Nihongo 4. Students will be instructed on how to self-critique one’s pronunciations. Japanese word games such as tongue-twisters, acrostics, palindromes and onomatopoeia will be incorporated, if time permits.

title: Cultures of Love in Modern Japan
description: In contemporary Japanese society, rules and guidelines govern discourses and practices of romance and affection. This course discusses how ideas from contemporary Japanese popular cultural texts (comics, novels, television dramas, nonfiction guidebooks, websites, social networking services, and others) influence the thinking and culture of human beings. The course also explores how the rules and styles of love are continuously modified, negotiated, and performed, particularly in an urban context. Further, the course considers the metamorphosis of intimacy and how this affects life in the postmodern era. Students are expected to gain a deeper understanding of the nature of love in Japanese culture and how concepts of love influence urban life.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Japan
description: This course introduces the social scientific study of gender, sexuality, and family in Japan from the postwar to the contemporary period from a comparative perspective. As the course covers a lot of readings, writings, and discussions on the issues of gender and sexuality, students are expected to come to class prepared to discuss the readings and facilitate the class discussion. For many, Japan represents a sweeping stereotype of extreme gender norms vis-à-vis contemporary Euro-American gender norms and manifestations. Such stereotypes are employed not only by outsiders to critique the society ethnocentrically, but also by some natives as well. Both sides frequently comment on the ways gender and gendered expectations shape and even determine contemporary experiences of “being Japanese.” Furthermore, stereotypes about gender and sexuality in Japan frequently overlap with and draw from broader stereotypes about Japan vis-à-vis other Asian societies and Asian societies vis-à-vis Western societies.By identifying these stereotypes and also critically questioning what gender means and how it is being shaped in and shaping contemporary Japan, this course will offer an entry into theories of gender studies and sexuality, and also introduce tools to critically analyze cultural differences manifested in the issues of gender and sexuality while at the same time learning more about Japanese society and your own society. Moving between historical and contemporary definitions of gender, sexuality, and family to look at change and continuity of gendered life ways in Japan, the course is divided into five sections addressing issues of: 1) Defining Gender and Gender Stereotypes; 2) Gender and Social Institutions; 3) Gender Construction / Performance; 4) The Politics of Sexuality and Identity; and 5) Gender and “Marginality.” In each section we investigate cultural constructions of gender, sexuality, and family and key themes that revolve around them: identity, class, morality and life course in contemporary Japan. At the end of each section we will take time to reflect on gender and sexuality in Asia more broadly. Class sessions will consist of lecture sessions devoted to explaining the readings in context and tutorial sections for facilitating active discussions and student presentations. Assignments for the course will ask students for active participation and weekly discussion questions, a reflective mid-term essay, and a final exam.
outcome: By the end of the course students will be able to demonstrate knowledge of social theories and approaches to gender and sexuality, discern stereotypes from social facts, and contextualize and analyze gendered and gendering socio-cultural phenomena. Students will also be able to construct analytical essays, give power-point presentations, and lead academic discussions.

title: Japanese Management
description: This course introduces the historical and social development of present Japanese management practices and systems. It aims to equip students with better understanding of Japanese business people, to establish mutual understanding, and to help students learn to collaborate with staff from Japan so as to achieve common objectives.

title: Japanese Literature
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a historical outline of Japanese literature. Major works and writers of different periods will be introduced through Chinese/English translation or the original works if students possess sufficient Japanese reading ability.
outcome: Students are expected to understand the history of Japanese literature, and its influence to traditional and modern Japanese culture. They can appreciate classics written by Japanese writers, and analyse Japanese cultural phenomena with a critical perspective.

title: Japan's International Relations
description: This course examines the making of Japanese foreign policy and diplomatic initiatives from the early postwar period to the present from historical, sociological and political science perspectives. In particular, the current shift from US-Japan bilateral relationship to Japan-China triangular relationship as the cornerstone of Japanese diplomacy will be closely investigated. The first part of the course aims to provide an academic framework for the study of Japanese diplomacy, such as the mechanism in foreign policy making, the interplay between diplomacy and domestic politics, and the rise of soft power and cultural diplomacy. The second part introduces Japan’s foreign policy with US, China, and ASEAN. The third part deals with traditional and non-traditional security issues as well as regionalism.

title: Japan in East Asian Politics: Visions of Regional Integration
description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge and framework of analysing the on-going process of regional integration in East Asia and Japan's role exercised in the process. The first part examines basic knowledge on world politics and movements related to regional integration, including the EU. The second part examines in details of various movements of regional integration in East Asia with a focus on Japan's intention and practices and provides perspectives of future visions of East Asia.

title: Introduction to Japanese Economy
description: This course introduces different aspects of the Japanese economy. Major topics include industrial structure, employment, trade, foreign investment and finance. Special emphasis will be put on the analysis of their structure, government policies and current problems.

title: The History of 20th Century Japan
description: This course explores modern Japan, which underwent perhaps the most striking transformation of any country in the modern world. Narrowly escaping colonization, Japan transformed into one of the most important imperial and economic powers in the world. Modern Japan is also doubly fascinating for a comparative take on the great themes of modern global history: the social upheavals and transformations of capitalism and democracy, the rise and fall of modern imperialism, the experience of total war, and the spread of a mass consumer culture. This course examines the invention of new traditions and the construction of a new national identity, the rise and fall of empire, the devastation of World War II, and the astonishing postwar economic growth and puzzling stagnation in contemporary times. This course explores how people in Japan have dealt with the dilemmas of modernity that challenge us all.
outcome: By the end of the semester, students will have achieved: (1) Understand the major dynamics and trends of modern Japanese history (2) Deepen their understanding of modern and contemporary Japanese society  (3) Learn to write logical and coherent historical papers
syllabus: Week 1: Course Introduction; Meiji Restoration This will explore the arrival of the “Black Ships” and the reasons behind the overthrow of the Shogunate.  Week 2: Civilization and Enlightenment This week deals with Japan’s Meiji-era cultural/intellectual Westernization.  Week 3: Constructing the Meiji State This week explores the creation of Japan’s new political structure and the fruits of Japan’s modern revolution.   Week 4: “Rich Nation, Strong Army,” and the Making of Japan’s Empire This week deals with the logic and goals of becoming an empire in the age of imperialism.  Week 5: State and Society in Japan’s Imperial Democracy This week investigates the move toward party leadership, and the linkages between state and society in Taishō era Japan.  Week 6: The Roaring ‘20s, and Tensions in Modern Life This week explores the tensions brought about by capitalism and Japanese modernity.  Week 7: Crisis of Capitalism and Empire This week explores the Great Depression and the “Manchurian Incident.”  Week 8: Japan at War This week deals with the “China Incident,” Japanese ultra-nationalism, and the move toward all-out war in the Asia-Pacific. It also deals with daily life during wartime.   Week 9: America’s Japan: Occupation and Aftermath This week studies the American Occupation of Japan and its aftermath.  Week 10: Cold War Realignments and the Conservative Political Resurgence This week highlights the remarkable conservative resurgence in Japan, and its battles with the progressive left.   Week 11: Postwar Economy and Society This week deals with the growth of a middle class and meritocratic society in the postwar years, and the remarkable “economic miracle.”  Week 12: A New Global Power? This week discusses the Plaza Accord, the Japanese economic bubble, and the birth of Japan as a new global power in the 1980s.  Week 13: The Lost Decades, 3.11, and Beyond This week has students cover important issues from the last 25 years of Japanese society.

title: Asia at War
description: World War II remains the most total and bloodiest conflict in world history. Fought on multiple fronts on three continents, the war witnessed a complex mesh of ideologies and war aims. It wrought unparalleled destruction and targeted civilians to an unprecedented degree. It has been the only war to date in which atomic weapons were used. The war pitted empires against each other and led to the fall of many of those global empires. This course will focus on World War II in Asia. It uses Japanese history as a window into global processes, and also places the war in its proper regional context. Beginning with World War I, this course journeys through the crisis of East Asian international relations in 1920s and 1930s to the outbreak of a multi-front war in East and Southeast Asia. It considers the war’s impact on empires and nations, soldiers and victims, and peoples throughout the region. And it explores the legacies that remain visible across the region today.
outcome: Understand the causes and legacies of World War II in Asia. In the process, they will learn the ways in which the war helped shape the contemporary world. Read academic works and learn to clearly articulate the main arguments of academic writing. Engage confidently in class-time debates and improve their argumentative reasoning.    Write research papers that make use of primary source documents (the documents analyzed can be in any language). Understand historical events from multiple perspectives, and become more critical of primary source documents.
syllabus: Week 1:  Introduction and Course OutlineWeek 2:  World War I and Empires at WarThis week focuses on World War I in Asia, the emergence of Japan as a world power during the wartime years, and Japanese wartime imperialism in China and the Asia-Pacific.Week 3:  Aftermath of War: The Washington System and its DiscontentsThis week centers on the dramatic global postwar rejection of the diplomacy of imperialism and war that was symbolized by the "Washington System".  It was this system that Japan would seek to change and then overthrow in the 1930s.Week 4:  The Global Depression and Crisis in ManchuriaThis week focuses on the issues leading to the Manchurian Incident of September 1931 and the renewed Japanese imperialism of the 1930s.Week 5:  Ultranationalism, Insubordination, Rebellion, and the Question of FascismJapan's renewed imperialism was accompanied by ultranationalism in society and insubordination and even rebellion with the military. This class will use these issues to question the nature of Japanese "facism".Week 6:  Japan and China: Toward Total WarThis week focuses on the lead up to and the initial stages of Japan's total war in China from 1937.Week 7:  Japan Lashes Out! The Attacks of December 8, 1941This week will focus on the beginning of the Pacific War, or the so-called War for Greater East Asia.  Students will have a fun group activity for the majority of the class to try to avoid the war from happening!Week 8:  Asia Under JapanThis week will show how Japan sought to rule much of Asia, and how its efforts changed throughout the course of the war.Week 9:  The War in Everyday LifeThis week will show the impact the war had on daily life in Japan.Week 10:  Learning How to DieThis week will focus on the cultural history of fighting a losing war, and how that led Japanese government and mass media to enshrine death as a meaningful way to fight.Week 11:  Endgame: The Japanese SurrenderThis week will center on the events surrounding the Japanese surrender, including the controversial decisions to use firebombing and atomic weaponry as weapons of war.Week 12:  From War to PeaceThis week will focus on how the war's end reshaped Japan, its empire and the region.Week 13:  The War in Retrospect: Legacies and MemoriesThis final week will continue to show the extraordinary legacies of the age of total war on both Japan and Asia.

title: The Construction of Japanese Ethnic and Cultural Identity
description: Though extensively influenced by ancient China, Japan has developed into one of the world’s most distinctive cultures. Japan’s remote geographic location made it possible for changes to come relatively slowly, and except for the postwar reform, most innovations resulted from the voluntary adoption of foreign cultures rather than external pressure. This course discusses how Japanese civilization, i.e. the Yamato nation, and the Japanese language were formed. How Japanese society arose through the localization of foreign cultures will be one of the major themes covered. Efforts will be made to identify nation-wide characteristics, if any, and investigate how they were cultivated over the centuries. Special attention will be paid to the similarities that can be found between the two major social reforms in modern Japanese history, i.e. the Meiji Restoration and postwar reform, and to the question of how these reforms influence Japan society today.
outcome: 1) to develop a proper understanding of Japanese culture from a cultural historical point of view;  2) to properly articulate different topics with relevant historical contexts of Japan;  3) to critically examine popular and yet controversial theories and/or perceptive frameworks for analyzing Japanese culture; and   4) to understand the specificity and universality of Japanese culture.
syllabus: 1. Features of the Japanese Language: A Cultural and Historical Analysis To discuss how Japanese people i.e. Jomon people, Yayoi people and Yamato nation and the Japanese language were possibly formed.  2. The Early Horse-rider Theory and the Modified Hypothesis To discuss the pros and cons of the popular and yet controversial theory for analyzing how Yamato nation was formed.  3. Features of Japanese Cultural History To introduce the features of Japanese cultural history i.e. the separation of power and authorities, top-down social reforms, cultural advancement by external stimulations, etc. How the Edo government ruled the people (only samurai and farmers will be focused) will also be discussed.   4. Essence of Japanese Aesthetics To introduce makoto, aware, okashi, wabi & sabi, iki.  5. Zen and Japanese Tea Ceremony To introduce how Japanese tea ceremony was developed in a Japanese way.  6. Rice Growing in Edo Period and the Correlations between the Government and the Farmers To introduce how Japanese government helped and exploited the farmers in Edo period.  7. Double Structure of Japanese People’s Mentality in Meiji Period To introduce how the country advanced but the people were confused in Meiji period.   8. The Ideal and Reality of the Peace Constitution Drawn up after the Second World War To introduce how the Postwar Japan was reformed and changed under the overwhelming influence by the GHQ.   9. title: Everyday Life and Cultural Representation in Modern Japan
description: This course aims at examining the dynamics between everyday life, modernity, and the representation of tradition in modern Japan from two different perspectives. Part One of the course introduces students Japanese responses to the idea of modernity, and the cultural transformation and social crisis over the course of Japan’s modernization. Part Two examines the continuation of, rapprochement with, and appropriation of traditional elements in the cultural lives of contemporary Japan.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to be able to critically discuss the ideas and effects of modernization in Japan in different aspects, such as gender, urban space, and environmental problems. 2) Students are expected to be able to critically analyze the representation of tradition in contemporary Japan. 3) Students are expected to develop their own critical angles to examine and interpret the meanings of Japanese cultural products, such as films, novels, and anime. 4) Students are expected to strengthen their reading skills in a range of academic disciplines, including anthropology, cultural studies, and modern history.

title: Selected Topics in Japanese Grammar
requirements:
Prerequisites: JASP2460 or 2480 or equivalent competence in Japanese
Not for students who have taken JASP4180,4310,4330,4350,4360,4370,4380,4390,4440,4450,4510,4520
description: This course will focus on the grammatical structure and characteristics of the Japanese language. Students will renew their grammatical understanding of Japanese and analyze it from a systematic point of view. Some of the major parts of speech, such as nouns, adverbs, adjectives, Rentaishi, particles, including their significance, characteristics, and functions will also be covered and discussed.
outcome: Students are expected to be able to describe the grammatical structure and the characteristics of the Japanese language. Students are expected to be able to make use of the methods learnt to analyze Japanese grammar. Students are expected to be able to use nouns, adverbs, adjective, Rentaishi, and particles, in appropriate and accurate ways.

Interesting nouns in Japanese (e.g. nouns without any meanings, extremely long noun phases, etc)3.The transformation of おはようございます (“Good morning” in Japanese)4. Making good use of them to make your Japanese more authentic: Adverbs5.The part of speech with unique origin and usages: Keiyoudoushi (na-adjective)6.The unique part of speech in Japanese: Rentaishi7.The part of speech that is very important but often get omitted: particles

title: Japan and Hong Kong
description: This course investigates the relationships between Japan and Hong Kong from historical and sociological perspectives, focusing on the activities of the Japanese in Hong Kong from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. Main topics for lecture and discussion include early Japanese residents in prewar Hong Kong, Hong Kong under Japan's occupation, Japan-Hong Kong economic and cultural ties, the Japanese community in Hong Kong, the Japanese popular culture boom in Hong Kong and the Hong Kong culture in Japan. Guest lecture, panel discussion, study tour and debate may be organized to supplement lectures and discussion.
outcome: (1) 學習日本與香港歷史，了解港日交流的各種發展與現況 (2) 探究日本文化對香港的衝擊及本地化過程，從而對當前的生活背景有更深體會 (3) 了解香港流行文化在日本的流行情況，展望亞洲創意工業機緣與前景

title: Japanese Youth Cultures in Asia
description: Youth cultures have played a critical role in shaping Japanese public attitudes and debates, consumer movements, and institutions in the postwar period. Japanese youth-oriented popular cultures are currently reshaping the cultural landscape across much of Asia. This course explores Japan's youth cultures and introduces the diversity of youth experiences in Japan. It further allows students to explore the influence of Japanese youth cultures in other Asian societies. The course encourages students to compare youth cultures in Japan with that of China, Hong Kong, and North America. The course will also consider the rise of transnational youth cultures based on movements of people, ideas, and images across national borders. It will explore the emergence of a Japan influenced youth popular culture in Asia as well as the particular local contexts in which the experiences of youth take on meanings for individuals.
outcome: Analyze the nature and influence of the knowledge from Japanese Studies  Evaluate how Japanese culture influence the generation’s ideology Understand how concepts of Japanese-ness are established and developed Elaborate how Japanese culture is localized and metamorphosed after participations of different stakeholders and local agencies.
